questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines is generally not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Hepatitis B
  2. Influenza
  3. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  4. Pneumococcal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c only

 

HPV vaccine is not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age because it is only approved for use up to 45 years of age. The other vaccines mentioned can be safely and effectively administered to elderly individuals based on their risk factors and previous vaccination status.

 

Other Options:

 

a. Hepatitis B vaccine: This is conditionally indicated in elderly individuals who have not previously received the vaccine and have risk factors.

 

b. Influenza vaccine: This is strongly recommended annually for elderly individuals as they are at high risk for complications from influenza infection.

 

d. Pneumococcal vaccine: This is a crucial vaccine for elderly individuals. The current recommendation in India is to give PCV13 followed by PPSV23 to provide comprehensive protection against pneumococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The age-based restrictions for HPV vaccination (approved only up to age 45) and the core vaccines recommended for elderly individuals (pneumococcal, influenza, and conditional hepatitis B vaccination).

 

The only non-recommended vaccine in this list for those over 65 years is HPV, while pneumococcal, influenza, and hepatitis B vaccines may all be indicated based on individual risk factors and previous vaccination status.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin

 

Explanation

 

All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

 

Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

  • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.

 

Stimulation of ECL Cells:

 

  1. Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  2. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  3. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.

 

Role of Serotonin:

 

  • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text:
Among the given statements, which one would lead you to consider primary amenorrhea as a possibility? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
  2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
  3. High levels of TSH and short stature
  4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation in a girl who has not attained menarche by a certain age or who lacks secondary sexual characteristics. Specifically:

 

1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age: This is a classic indicator of primary amenorrhea, particularly if secondary sexual characteristics have developed. It is an age by which menstruation should have started if there are signs of puberty.

 

2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche: Thelarche, or breast development, typically occurs around ages 9 to 13. If menarche has not occurred within 3 years after thelarche, it is a reason to investigate primary amenorrhea.

 

4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age: The absence of breast development by age 13 indicates a delay in puberty and warrants evaluation for primary amenorrhea if menstruation has not begun by this age.

 

Other Option:

 

3. High levels of TSH and short stature: While high TSH and short stature may indicate thyroid dysfunction or other endocrine issues, they are not direct indicators of primary amenorrhea. These findings might contribute to secondary causes of amenorrhea or other growth disorders but are not themselves diagnostic criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paracetamol


N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a metabolite of paracetamol drug toxicity.

 

NAPQI is highly reactive and has high affinity for sulfydryl groups. It causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione (GSH) that acts as a source of sulfhydryl group and then excreted into the urine.

 

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC), which provides the sulfhydryl group. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body.

 

The maximum recommended dose of acetaminophen is 4g/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Aspirin overdose primarily causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and can lead to salicylate poisoning.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac toxicity does not involve NAPQI. Diclofenac is an NSAID that can cause gastrointestinal and renal toxicity.

 

Option D. Ketorolac: Ketorolac toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Like other NSAIDs, ketorolac can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and renal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NAPQI is a toxic metabolite produced during the metabolism of paracetamol. In cases of paracetamol overdose, NAPQI accumulates and causes liver damage. The antidote for paracetamol toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which helps detoxify NAPQI by replenishing glutathione and providing sulfhydryl groups.

questions.text: The procedure in the image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure used for? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

  • Methylene blue dye, along with other tracers, is commonly employed in sentinel lymph node biopsy procedures. Sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that cancer is likely to spread to from a primary tumor. By injecting the dye around the tumor, these sentinel lymph nodes can be identified and biopsied to determine if cancer has spread to them. This helps in staging and planning further treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLN biopsy rationale:

 

Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node, before draining into the other nodes.

 

So, if sentinel lymph node is positive, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.

 

If the sentinel node is tumor free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

 

The nodes can be identified using:

 

  • Fluorescein dye
  • Methylene blue
  • Radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin

 

The recommended site of injection is in the subdermal plexus surrounding the nipple.

 

This is used in patients with clinically node-negative disease.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior Limb

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most commonly affected area in cases of hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke. This area carries the corticospinal tract, which is essential for motor control. When the posterior limb is compromised, it disrupts the corticospinal pathway, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body from the lesion.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: Primarily involved in visual processing. Damage here would likely lead to visual field defects rather than motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Anterior limb: Primarily associated with cognitive and emotional functions due to its connectivity between the thalamus and the frontal lobe. Lesions here generally do not cause hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Sublentiform: Involved in auditory and gustatory pathways, thus unrelated to motor control functions affected in hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ischemic stroke, damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in hemiplegia because of the disruption of corticospinal tracts. This knowledge aids in accurate stroke localization and informs rehabilitation strategies to help regain motor functions.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24-h pH monitoring

 

24-hr pH monitoring is done in GERD. The above image is suggestive of gradual narrowing in lower esophagus, likely to be achalasia.

 

This is a test that measures the pH of the esophagus over a 24-hour period to assess for abnormal acid reflux. While not typically necessary for the diagnosis of achalasia cardia, 24-hour pH monitoring may be used to rule out gastroesophageal reflux disease as a potential cause of dysphagia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timed barium study: In the case of achalasia cardia, the barium will be retained in the esophagus for more than five minutes and the study may reveal a dilated esophagus with a 'bird's beak' appearance at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Endoscopy may be used to rule out other potential causes of dysphagia, such as esophageal cancer, and to obtain biopsy samples if needed.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry: This is a diagnostic test that measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus during swallowing. In the case of achalasia cardia, esophageal manometry may reveal incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. It is the test of choice for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

 

The right ventricle is the marked object. The diagonal arterial supply does not reach it.

 

The anterior interventricular artery, which supplies the left ventricle, has a branch called the diagonal artery. Between 30 to 50 percent of the population has this.

 

The right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery, provide the right ventricle with the majority of its blood.

 

One or two anterior right ventricular branches emerge from the anterior interventricular artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right coronary artery: This is correct in terms of not being an exception. The right coronary artery primarily supplies the right atrium and the right ventricle, including the structure marked as 'E', which is the right ventricle.

 

Option B. Anterior interventricular artery: This artery primarily supplies the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles. Although it predominantly serves the left ventricle, it also sends branches such as the anterior right ventricular branches that can reach the right ventricle.

 

Option C. Marginal artery: This artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, specifically supplies the right ventricle, which is the structure marked as 'E'.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked by red arrow in the image below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

 

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

 

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

 

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) except Superior Oblique (Trochlear nerve, IV) and Lateral rectus (Abducens, VI)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique and the lateral rectus. It does not innervate the structure marked in the image, which is the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve: This nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the face and does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the superior oblique.

 

Option D. Abducens nerve: This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle only, which abducts the eye. It does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle, is uniquely innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally. This muscle functions to depress, abduct, and internally rotate the eyeball, and it is the only extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve. Remembering this specific innervation is crucial for diagnosing and managing ocular motility disorders.

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apoptosis

 

Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are both seen in apoptosis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of traumatic cell death that results from acute cellular injury. It is characterized by uncontrolled cell lysis, inflammation, and the release of intracellular contents into the extracellular space. Necrosis does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways seen in apoptosis.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis that is caspase-independent but involves the receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3). It is similar to necrosis but is regulated and has distinct signaling pathways that do not include the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Option D. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation, typically involving caspase-1, which processes pro-inflammatory cytokines. It does not involve the intrinsic or extrinsic apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is characterized by both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, which lead to programmed cell death in a controlled and regulated manner.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

 

Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

 

The Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV), belongs to the family of DNA viruses Herpeseviridae. It causes Kaposi sarcoma (a vascular malignancy) and B cell lymphoproliferative diseases such as primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD).

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

 

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is catalase-positive and does not typically exhibit bacitracin sensitivity. It is identified by coagulase testing and its ability to grow in the presence of high salt concentrations.

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod and is not identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Bacillus species are Gram-positive rods that form spores and are not typically identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endothelial cells

 

vWF is made in endothelial cells and megakaryocytes. vWF is also present in the subendothelial matrix of normal blood vessels and the α-granules of platelets. Following endothelial injury, exposure of subendothelial vWF causes adhesion of platelets, primarily via the glycoprotein lb (GpIB) platelet receptor.

 

  • Endothelial cells are responsible for producing and secreting the majority of plasma vWF. They synthesize vWF and store it in Weibel-Palade bodies, specialized storage granules in the endothelial cells. Upon vascular injury, vWF is released into the bloodstream, where it binds to platelets and subendothelial structures, facilitating the formation of a platelet plug.
  • Additionally, megakaryocytes synthesize vWF, which is stored in the alpha granules of platelets and released during platelet activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelets: While platelets contain vWF in their alpha granules and release it upon activation, they are not the major source of plasma vWF. Instead, their vWF contributes to local hemostasis at the site of injury.

 

Option B. Lymphocytes: Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in the immune response and do not produce or release vWF.

 

Option C. Macrophages: Macrophages are involved in phagocytosis and the immune response, but they do not produce vWF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major source of plasma von Willebrand factor (vWF) is endothelial cells, which release vWF into the bloodstream upon vascular injury to facilitate platelet adhesion.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1253

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. It is the most common sporadic renal tumor
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4  

 

CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA (Most Common variant)

 

  • Mutation - VHL gene (Occasionally associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3.
  • Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions.
  • Radiographic findings - Hypervascular mass with homogeneous enhancement
  • Gross: Solid mass with a golden-yellow appearance
  • Histopathology - Clear cytoplasm due to washing of accumulated glycogen and lipid droplets. Prominent vasculature and sheets of polygonal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3, not long.

 

Statement 3: Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, not distal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clear cell carcinoma of the kidney is the most common sporadic renal tumor and is characterized by cells with intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat, as well as an association with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1847-1849

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful
  4. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

 

Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.

 

H. ducreyi is a small, fastidious gram-negative rod that requires an enriched growth medium cultivated in a high humidity, CO2-enriched environment. On Gram stain, long strands of organisms are seen in a pattern often referred to as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" in appearance.

 

Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre." Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in "kissing ulcers." The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months.

 

Other Option:


D. Groove sign: This is typically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and not chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate


Calcium oxalate crystals are typically bipyramidal or envelope-shaped. These crystals are common in various conditions, including hyperoxaluria and ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Calcium phosphate:  crystals form asymmetric rosettes.

 

Option C. Uric acid:  crystals are rhomboid forming rosettes, polychromatophilic in Polarized Microscope.

 

Option D. Cystine:  crystals are hexagonal, and one of the hardest crystals.

 

Note - Monohydrate crystal – dumbbell shaped

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate crystals are bipyramidal or envelope-shaped.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and results in severe intellectual and physical disability. It is nearly always seen in females. Males with the genetic mutation for Rett syndrome usually die shortly after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asperger syndrome: It is a milder variant of autism and can occur in both males and females, although it is more commonly diagnosed in males.

 

Option C. Selective mutism: An anxiety disorder in which a person who is normally capable of speech cannot speak in specific situations or to specific people. It affects both males and females.

 

Option D. Atypical autism: Also known as Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS), it can occur in both males and females.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: What is the approximate age of a person in whom the medial end of the clavicle is fused and also the sternum is completely fused? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. >25 years

 

Approximate age for the given person with fused medial end of clavicle and completely fused sternum is most likely >25 years.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following has the worst prognosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Partial Bilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Palsy

Explanation for Correct Answer:

Partial Bilateral RLN palsy involves selective paralysis of only the abductor fibers (as per Semon’s Law), while the adductor fibers remain intact. This results in both vocal cords being pulled medially into the median position, due to the unopposed action of the intact adductors and the cricothyroid muscle (innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

In this median position, the glottic airway is severely compromised, leading to inspiratory stridor, dyspnea, and often acute airway obstruction, despite the voice being relatively preserved.

This situation is life-threatening and usually requires an emergency tracheostomy, making it the worst prognosis among all types.

Explanation for Other Options:

A. Partial Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Only abductor fibers are affected on one side.
  • The affected vocal cord moves to median position, but the contralateral healthy cord compensates.
  • Voice may be mildly hoarse, but airway is adequate.
  • Good prognosis.

C. Complete Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both abductor and adductor fibers are lost on one side.
  • Cord lies in paramedian position (due to passive pull of cricothyroid).
  • Other side compensates for both voice and airway.
  • Moderate prognosis.

D. Complete Bilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both cords lie in paramedian position (both abduction and adduction lost).
  • Airway is compromised but slightly better than in partial bilateral palsy.
  • Often needs tracheostomy, but not as acute as partial bilateral.
  • Serious but not worst prognosis

Semon’s Law:

In progressive organic lesions of the RLN, abductor fibers (posterior cricoarytenoid) are more vulnerable and affected first, while adductor fibers are more resistant. Hence, early (partial) palsy affects only abduction, leading to dangerous median cord positioning.

Comparison Table:

Educational Objective:

Partial bilateral RLN palsy carries the worst prognosis due to medial cord positioning from intact adductors and SLN action, causing life-threatening airway obstruction despite relatively preserved voice.

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

choices.text: Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse
Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil
Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following options is wrong about ascaris lumbricoides? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse

 

Heavy infection with rectal prolapse is NOT associated with Ascaris lumbricoides infection. This clinical manifestation is actually characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Most infections are asymptomatic: Most Ascaris infections are indeed asymptomatic, particularly in immunocompetent individuals. This is an important clinical feature of ascariasis.

 

Option C. Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil: Ascaris eggs can be either embryonated or unembryonated. The unembryonated eggs require time in soil to develop and become infective. 

 

Option D. Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms: Ascaris larvae migrate through the lungs as part of their life cycle (pulmonary phase). During this migration, they can cause respiratory symptoms including cough, wheezing, and asthma-like symptoms, known as Löffler's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rectal prolapse is a characteristic complication of heavy Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection, not Ascaris lumbricoides infection. Ascaris causes pulmonary symptoms during its larval migration phase and is often asymptomatic in its intestinal phase.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

 

Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas. Elevated levels of serum lipase are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. It is a critical diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Upper GI endoscopy is used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, which may help diagnose conditions like peptic ulcers or esophagitis. However, in this case, the symptoms and clinical findings are more indicative of acute pancreatitis rather than upper GI issues.

 

Option B. Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test is used to detect recent alcohol consumption. While the patient has a history of heavy alcohol use, this test won't provide information about the current medical condition, such as pancreatitis.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) can be a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and assessing its severity. However, in many cases, a serum lipase test is ordered first because it's a quicker and less invasive way to diagnose acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

 

Thiamine deficiency affects the activity of PDH, which is an enzyme complex responsible for converting pyruvate (a product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, a key molecule in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When PDH is inhibited, pyruvate cannot enter the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate, which is then converted to lactic acid, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is not directly related to lactic acidosis in the context of thiamine deficiency. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is involved in gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. It does not directly contribute to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in the final step of glycolysis, where it catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not directly associated with lactic acidosis due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.

 

 

Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:

  1. PDH
  2. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Additional Information:

  • Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: Match the following:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correct matching of the diseases with their diagnostic techniques is as follows:

 

  1. Leprosy - d. Split skin smear
  2. Tinea capitis - c. KOH wet mount
  3. Contact dermatitis - b. Patch test
  4. Lupus vulgaris - a. Biopsy

 

Other options:

 

The other options provided in the multiple choice (A, B, and C) are incorrect matchings of the diseases and diagnostic techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each skin condition has a specific diagnostic test:

 

  • Leprosy is diagnosed using a split skin smear, typically from the earlobe.
  • Tinea capitis, a fungal infection, is diagnosed using a KOH wet mount of skin, nail, or hair scrapings.
  • Contact dermatitis is evaluated using a patch test to identify allergens.
  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is diagnosed through a skin biopsy to look for granulomas.

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distant range

 

An abrasion collar is a ring of abraded skin around the entrance wound of a bullet. It is caused by the bullet's friction as it penetrates the skin. This feature can be found at any distance, including distant range. However, additional features such as singeing, blackening, and tattooing are present only at closer ranges. Since the question states that the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar, it indicates that none of the other close-range features are present, suggesting a distant range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact range: At contact range, there would be singeing, blackening, and tattooing right at the margins of the wound, as well as potential muzzle imprint and burning due to the close proximity of the firearm.

 

Option B. Close range: At close range, there would be significant blackening and tattooing around the wound, indicating the firearm was discharged from a short distance but not in contact with the skin.

 

Option C. Near range: At near range, there would still be some blackening and tattooing around the wound, but these features diminish with increasing distance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are five features of firearm entry wound (inner most to outermost):

 

  • Grease Collar (inner most)
  • Abrasion collar
  • Singeing
  • Blackening
  • Tattooing (outer most)

 

Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.

 

Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance

questions.text: Which of the following is the first investigation in newborn for audiological assessment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions)

 

OAE is the first choice for newborn hearing screening because:

 

  • It is a simple, quick, and non-invasive test
  • Can be done with a portable device
  • Involves placing a probe in the infant's ear that sends sound stimulus and captures emissions from outer hair cells
  • If result is "pass", indicates normal hearing
  • If result is "refer", then BERA is done as the next step
  • Tests the integrity of outer hair cells in the cochlea
  • Can be performed while baby is sleeping or quiet

Other Options:

 

Option A. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry): Though essential for newborn screening, it is more complex and time-consuming than OAE. It is used as a second-line test if OAE results are abnormal.

Option B. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry): Not suitable for newborns as it requires active participation and response from the subject, which newborns cannot provide.

 

Option D. Impedance: Not appropriate as first-line screening in newborns as it primarily tests middle ear function and requires some cooperation from the subject.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OAE is the first-line screening test for newborn hearing assessment due to its simplicity, speed, and non-invasive nature.

 

Newborn screening of hearing:

 

  • Here we test otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA).
  • Outer hair cells in cochlea emit these very low intensity sounds (OAE) & they can be collected by a microphone kept in EAC.
  • Normal OAE means cochlear hair cells are functioning normally and cochlea is normally functioning.
  • BERA tests the integrity of auditory nerve (auditory pathway from cochlea to brain). It is an objective test.
    • Here we give a sound stimulus and check the electrical potentials that arise along the auditory pathway from cochlear nerve to brain.
    • Wave V is most prominent in BERA that corresponds to lateral lemniscus.
    • It is a non-invasive procedure. It is also an objective test (whereas PTA is a subjective test = result depends on the responses given by patient/subject).
  • Normal BERA means the cochlear nerve is intact and conducting sound impulses from cochlea to brain.
  • So, normal OAE and BERA will indicate an almost normal hearing pathway, hence used in newborn screening.
  • BERA is also used to check malingerers (people those who pretend deaf).

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

The RBC pipette, identifiable by its red bead, is primarily used for counting red blood cells in a blood sample. It is not suitable for the colorimetric estimation of hemoglobin, as it is not designed for colorimetric comparisons or for mixing the reagents involved in this method.

 

Other Options:

 

The colorimetric method for hemoglobin estimation, often referred to as Sahli's method, relies on comparing the color intensity of a hemoglobin solution to a standard comparator. The primary steps involve mixing a blood sample with N/10 HCl in a graduated hemoglobin tube, which then undergoes color comparison against a brown glass standard.

 

Key Tools Used in Sahli's Method:

 

Option B. Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube: Used to mix blood with hydrochloric acid and measure the resulting color intensity.

 

Option C. Comparator with brown glass standard: Helps in comparing the color of the hemoglobin solution to determine the concentration.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: Utilized to accurately measure and transfer the blood sample into the graduated hemoglobin tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

 

Summary Table:

choices.text: Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spherical cells may be seen

 

G6PD deficiency can have spherical red cells.

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD. is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of NADPH. NADPH helps in keeping glutathione in a reduced state (GSH). This reduced glutathione acts as a defense against oxidative damage.

 

In G6PD deficiency, RBCs are exposed to oxidants. These cross-linking of the reactive sulfhydryl groups in the globin chain of hemoglobin. These are then deposited as inclusions in RBC membranes as Heinz bodies. When these RBCs pass-through spleen, macrophages pluck out these membrane inclusions. The remaining cells are seen as bite cells. Less severely damaged cells lose a part of their membrane, forming spherocytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spectrin: Spectrin is a part of the RBC membrane skeleton. It is commonly defective in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution: Normal biconcave RBCs have a bit of an 'extra space'. They can accommodate a little fluid when exposed to a hypotonic solution. But spherocytes have already lost a part of its membrane, so are relatively full. Hence if they are placed in a hypotonic solution, they absorb more fluid and result in lysis of RBCs. This forms the basis of testing spherocytes in Hereditary spherocytosis or G6PD and is known as osmotic fragility testing.

 

Option D. Cells lyse in hypertonic solution: Placing RBCs in a hypertonic solution causes them to lose water and shrink, but significant hemolysis does not typically occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

What is G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • A genetic enzymopathy, inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
  • G6PD is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway that generates NADPH, which helps maintain reduced glutathione (GSH).
  • GSH protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage.

 

What Happens in G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • Without enough G6PD, RBCs are vulnerable to oxidative stress, such as:
    • Infections
    • Drugs (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials)
    • Fava beans

 

Key peripheral smear findings:

 

  • Bite cells
  • Heinz bodies

 

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, red blood cells become spherical (spherocytes) due to oxidative damage and the removal of damaged membrane by the spleen, leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1198-1199

questions.text: Dr. Sharma was enthusiastically reviewing the results of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aimed to compare the therapeutic benefits of Drug A and Drug B. To her surprise, the data suggested a statistically significant difference between the two medications, indicated by a p-value of <0.005. However, after a comprehensive review and collaboration with other experts, it was established that in real-world settings, both drugs had essentially equivalent therapeutic outcomes. This error in interpretation, where a difference was falsely identified when none existed in reality, is best described by which of the following statistical terms? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Alpha error

 

  • In the given scenario, null hypothesis (H0) can be that the two drugs being the same in effectiveness is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will be that both drugs are different.
  • Since P-value was found to be < 0.005, means that data is statistically significant and thus, null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But it is already established that the null hypothesis is true and now if we accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false, this will be a type I error or alpha error.
  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

 

Statistical errors:

 

 

Type I Error (Alpha Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Probability of Type I error is given by ‘P – value’ (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error
  • Alpha is fixed in advance: P – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a)
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant

 

Type II Error (Beta Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)
  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

questions.text: Identify the condition: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The given image suggests a diagnosis of oculomotor nerve palsy because of the following features:

 

  • Left eye is deviating downwards and outwards.
  • Left eyelid is showing ptosis.
  • Left eye is unable to move upwards, downwards, or inwards towards the nose, indicating a lack of adduction, elevation, and depression.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (“down and out”) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Normal abduction due to the intact lateral rectus.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rectus palsy: Incorrect because. Medial rectus palsy specifically affects the ability of the eye to adduct (move inward toward the nose). If only the medial rectus were paretic, you would primarily observe limitation in horizontal inward movement of the affected eye without the associated ptosis, "down and out" positioning, or pupil involvement seen in the provided images. These broader symptoms indicate involvement of multiple muscles, which is characteristic of oculomotor nerve palsy, not isolated medial rectus palsy.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) palsy affects the superior oblique muscle, which primarily results in problems with eye rotation and vertical gaze, especially when looking downward and inward. Patients often present with vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt away from the side of the lesion to compensate for the misalignment, and no ptosis or pupillary involvement. The symptoms and the eye movement limitations shown in the images do not match those typically associated with trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) palsy results in failure of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to an inability to abduct the eye (move outward). Patients with this condition will have the affected eye positioned inward (medially) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus. This condition would not cause the ptosis or the "down and out" appearance nor the wide range of motion impairments displayed in the images, such as the inability to move the eye upward or downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve palsy significantly affects eye movement and eyelid function due to its role in innervating most of the extraocular muscles as well as lifting the eyelid. Diagnosis often involves a comprehensive evaluation of eye movement patterns, eyelid function, and pupil response, along with investigations to determine underlying causes. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause and managing symptoms to protect eye function and quality of life.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

choices.text: It does not depend on the macronutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is Thermogenic food? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High protein diet

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food (non-shivering thermogenesis).

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

Thermogenesis results from the presence of an uncoupling protein, thermogenin, in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High fat diet: While fats do contribute to thermogenesis, their specific dynamic action (SDA) is lower (15%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Option B. It does not depend on the macronutrients: This statement is incorrect, as the thermogenic effect of food does depend on the type of macronutrient consumed.

 

Option D. High carbohydrate diet: Carbohydrates have a lower thermogenic effect (5%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high protein diet has the highest thermogenic effect compared to fats and carbohydrates, leading to increased energy expenditure during digestion and metabolism.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:
