  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Interlobular septations
  2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation
  3. Pleural effusion
  4. Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of fungal pneumonia shows interlobular septations, peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation, and pleural effusion. HRCT of fungal pneumonia shows a nodule (not a cavity) with surrounding ground-glass opacities.

 

A nodule surrounded by ground-glass attenuation on HRCT imaging is seen in aspergillosis, candidiasis, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, coccidioidomycosis, and paracoccidioidomycosis. Cavitation on HRCT is seen in cases of community-acquired pneumonia due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, S. aureus, and gram-negative bacilli.

 

Aspergillosis is a fungal disease caused by Aspergillus species. Pulmonary aspergillosis has been categorized into saprophytic, allergic, and invasive forms.

 

HRCT findings of various types of aspergillosis are as follows:

 

  • Aspergilloma (saprophytic) shows a mass with soft-tissue attenuation, which is separated from the thoracic wall by airspace called the air crescent sign. Multiple nodules and bilateral involvement may be seen.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA-allergic) shows hypodense mucous plugs.
  • Angioinvasive aspergillosis shows multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation (halo sign) or pleural-based wedge-shaped areas of consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 4: Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities are more often associated with bacterial pneumonia or other causes of lung abscesses, not typically fungal pneumonia like aspergillosis or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

 

Option B. 1, 3, 4: While pleural effusion and interlobular septations are seen in fungal infections, cavitary lesions are more commonly associated with bacterial infections rather than fungal.

 

Option D. 2, 3, 4: This option includes cavitary lesions and pleural effusion but excludes interlobular septations, which are typically seen in fungal pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal pneumonia on HRCT typically shows interlobular septations, peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation, and pleural effusion with a nodule surrounded by ground-glass attenuation.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

The audiogram shows:

 

  • Both air and bone conduction curves are close together (no air-bone gap)
  • Normal hearing at lower frequencies (250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, 2000 Hz)
  • Sharp characteristic dip at 4000 Hz (4 kHz)
  • Bilateral involvement (shown in both red color for right ear and blue color for left ear)
  • This pattern is typically seen in factory workers exposed to loud noises

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: Shows conductive hearing loss with Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz (2 kHz), not 4000 Hz. Also has significant air-bone gap which is absent here.

Option C. Meniere's disease: Shows sensorineural hearing loss with up-sloping curve affecting low frequencies. Does not show characteristic dip at 4000 Hz.

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Shows a banana-shaped or trough pattern affecting middle frequencies, with poor speech discrimination. Does not show isolated 4000 Hz dip.

Educational Objective: 

 

Noise-induced hearing loss has a characteristic audiometric pattern with a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, typically bilateral and symmetrical.

 

  • Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve - Otosclerosis
  • Dip at 4000Hz - Noise induced hearing loss
  • Cookie bite audiogram - Congenital hearing loss mostly
  • Trough shaped audiogram - Acoustic neuroma
  • Up-sloping curve with SNHL - Meniere's disease (low frequencies involved)
  • Down-sloping curve with SNHL - Presycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis - age induced hearing loss. Treatment: hearing aid}.
  • High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a history of hyperglycemia and has had positive urine glucose tests on two separate occasions in the last six months. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician is considering various medications to manage the patient's condition and prevent potential complications, including renal involvement. Which of the following drugs will not delay renal involvement? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension. 
  • While effective at lowering blood pressure, it does not have specific renal protective effects and may not delay the progression of renal disease in diabetic patients. 
  • In fact, in some cases, thiazide diuretics can increase the risk of developing hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are a class of medications used to lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by promoting glucose excretion through the urine. Importantly, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Finerenone: It is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that reduces inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys. Clinical trials have demonstrated that finerenone can reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs (e.g., losartan, valsartan) are another class of medications used to manage hypertension and heart failure. Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing proteinuria and lowering intraglomerular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, while SGLT2 inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs have renal protective properties and can help delay renal involvement in diabetic patients, hydrochlorothiazide does not have these specific protective effects and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

FAT EMBOLISM

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
    • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
    • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
    • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
    • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
    • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion. Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient  remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

choices.text: They can differentiate
They can replicate
They can divide without any regulatory stimulus
They can regenerate damaged tissues

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about stem cells? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus.

 

Stem cells are characterized by their self-renewal properties and by their capacity to generate differentiated cell lineages. Stem cells give rise to all the various differentiated tissues. In adults, stem cells replace damaged cells and maintain tissue populations.

 

The properties of stem cells are:

 

  1. Obligatory asymmetric replication, in which with each stem cell division, one of the daughter cells retains its self-renewing capacity while the other enters a differentiation pathway
  2. Stochastic differentiation, in which a stem cell population is maintained by the balance between stem cell divisions that generate either two self-renewing stem cells or two cells that will differentiate.

 

The types of stem cells are:

 

  • Embryonic stem cells which are totipotent
  • Adult stem cells present in stem cell niches

 

The pluripotency of stem cells is due to factors like:

 

  • Oct3/4
  • Kif 4
  • Sox 2
  • c-myc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They can differentiate: This is true. Stem cells have the ability to differentiate into various specialized cell types.

 

Option B. They can replicate: This is true. Stem cells can self-renew, meaning they can replicate themselves to maintain the stem cell pool.

 

Option D. They can regenerate damaged tissues: This is true. Stem cells can help regenerate damaged tissues by differentiating into the necessary cell types to replace lost or damaged cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus; their division and differentiation are tightly controlled to maintain tissue homeostasis and prevent uncontrolled growth.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 165-170

questions.text: Which opening is present posterior to the marked structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eustachian tube

 

The marked structure appears to be the inferior turbinate, and:

 

  • The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate
  • This represents the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube
  • It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx
  • The opening appears as a vertical slit on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
  • Forms an elevation called torus tubarius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Onodi cell: This is a posterior ethmoid cell that extends superolateral to sphenoid sinus and is closely related to optic nerve. It is not located posterior to inferior turbinate.

Option C. Sphenopalatine foramen: This opening is located posterior to the middle turbinate (not inferior turbinate), about 1 cm behind its posterior end.

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: Opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above and posterior to superior turbinate, not inferior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate on the lateral wall of nasopharynx.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

 

Nernst equation: EMF (millivolts) = [61/Z] X log [Co / C]

 

  • EMF = electromotive force (Nernst potential)
  • z = charge of ion
  • Co = concentration outside
  • C = concentration inside

 

When using this formula, it is usually assumed that the potential in the extracellular fluid outside the membrane remains at zero potential, and the Nernst potential is the potential inside the membrane.

 

The sign of the potential is negative (-) if a negative ion is diffusing from outside to inside.

Therefore, Nernst potential = 61/-1 * log [100/10] =-61 * log [10] = - 61 mV

 

To get the charge, always check the final charge intracellularly.

 

The potential is negative intracellularly, so the Nernst equation comes out to be -61mV inside the membrane and the closest option is -60 mV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The equilibrium potential for an ion can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

questions.text:
Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects. (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

Column A

1. PUVA

2. Cyclosporine

3. Methotrexate

4. Acitretin

 

Column B

a. Abortifacient

b. Effective but is highly nephrotoxic

c. Long-term use increases the risk of skin cancer

d. Mucositis, teratogenic
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. PUVA (Psoralen + UVA):
    Long-term use increases the risk of skin cancer.
    PUVA is highly effective in treating psoriasis but has the potential for both acute and chronic side effects. Chronic use is associated with an increased risk of     non-melanoma skin cancer (such as squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma).
  2. Cyclosporine:
    Effective but is highly nephrotoxic.
    Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant primarily associated with     renal impairment (nephrotoxicity), metabolic disturbances, and an increased risk of malignancies. It is less frequently used now due to these side effects.
  3. Methotrexate:
    Abortifacient.
    Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist used to treat psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions. It has abortifacient properties and is used in the management of     molar pregnancies. Methotrexate is also associated with mucositis, teratogenicity, and hepatotoxicity.
  4. Acitretin:
    Mucositis, teratogenic.
    Acitretin, a systemic retinoid, is highly teratogenic and causes mucocutaneous side effects such as     mucositis and hyperlipidemia. Women are advised to avoid conception for 3 years after stopping acitretin due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d: This incorrectly matches Cyclosporine (a) with abortifacient properties, which is incorrect as this applies to Methotrexate. Methotrexate (3) should be associated with a, not Cyclosporine (2).

 

Option C. 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a: This mismatches PUVA and Cyclosporine. PUVA should be associated with the risk of skin cancer (c), not nephrotoxicity (b), and Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic, not linked to mucositis (d).

 

Option D. 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d: PUVA is associated with skin cancer risk, not nephrotoxicity, and Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic, not associated with skin cancer. This option misplaces the side effects for both PUVA and Cyclosporine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In psoriasis treatment, be aware of the side effects of key therapies:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer with long-term use.
  • Cyclosporine is highly nephrotoxic.
  • Methotrexate has abortifacient properties.
  • Acitretin causes mucositis and is highly teratogenic.

choices.text: Impact of a semi sharp-edged object
Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic comes to the casualty after being hurt in a fight with a stranger. A lacerated wound is seen over his skull. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of this lacerated wound? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

 

The laceration shown above is an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shearing force: Shearing force typically causes a different type of laceration, not the incised-like laceration seen in the image.

 

Option B. Impact of a semi sharp-edged object: This might cause a different wound pattern, more akin to a cut or a clean incision rather than a laceration.

 

Option C. Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue: This causes stretch lacerations, which do not match the appearance of the wound shown.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.

  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.

  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.

  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact

  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.

  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

questions.text: What is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug amongst the given drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ofloxacin

 

In general, Rifampicin is the most potent bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

But in cases of Rifampicin resistance, we use regimens consisting of Ofloxacin+ Clofazimine + Clarithromycin/Minocycline are used for 24 months.

 

Out of these, the fluoroquinolone Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a variety of bacterial infections but is not typically used or effective against Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that has broad antibacterial activity, including some activity against Mycobacterium species. However, it is not as potent as Ofloxacin in the treatment of leprosy.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that has some activity against Mycobacterium species but is less effective and less commonly used in the treatment of leprosy compared to Other Options: like Rifampicin and Ofloxacin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti-leprotic drug among the given options, especially used in cases where there is resistance to the standard first-line treatment with Rifampicin.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

questions.text: Match the following drugs in Column A with their contraindications in Column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to the following reasons:
    • It causes miosis and in patients with head injury who are in a comatose state, the progress of the patient after giving drugs is assessed by pupillary reaction. So, if the pupil already remains constricted due to morphine, the assessment of progress cannot be done.
    • Morphine leads to respiratory depression and if in the patients with head injury, if the respiratory rate is already depressed, it will get aggravated.
    • Respiratory depression will lead to accumulation of CO2, leading to vasodilatation and increased intracranial pressure.
  • Amiodarone can cause QT prolongation and even precipitate Torsade de pointes.
  • Vigabatrin is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is teratogenic.
  • Estrogen preparations are known to increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to its effects on pupil size and respiratory depression. Amiodarone is associated with QT prolongation and potential arrhythmias. Vigabatrin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy. Estrogen increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

questions.text: Cellular junctions present in a cardiac muscle are all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

 

Zonula occludens is the other name for the tight junction. It is absent in a cardiac muscle.

 

Cardiac muscle fibers are striated bound by sarcolemma with a centrally placed nucleus.

 

Myofibrils are embedded in the sarcoplasm.

 

Sarcomere of the cardiac muscle has all the contractile proteins, namely actin, myosin, troponin and tropomyosin. Cardiac muscle fiber is branched.

 

Intercalated disk - formed by the fusion of the membrane of the cardiac muscle branches.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Fascia adherens - broad intercellular junction both of sarcolemma and intercalated disc of cardiac muscle fibers that anchors actin filaments.

 

Option C. Gap junction - fused membranes adjacent muscle fibers form gap junctions. It is permeable to ions and it facilitates the rapid conduction of action potential from one fiber to another.

 

Option D. Macula adherens - Also called as desmosomes are intercellular junctions specialized for strong adhesion. They prevent the separation of cardiac myocytes during individual fiber contraction by binding to intracellular intermediate filaments (cytoskeleton), which joins cells together.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Zonula occludens are absent in cardiac muscle; instead, this muscle type prominently features fascia adherens, gap junctions, and macula adherens, which are essential for mechanical stability and coordinated contraction.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet fracture

 

The image shows a Chevallet fracture pattern. Chevallet fracture is a type of maxillofacial fracture that commonly occurs due to trauma. This type of fracture typically affects the lower jaw (mandible) and is characterized by a specific pattern of breakage along the jawline, often due to a direct impact. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jarjaway fracture: Also known as J-type fracture, has a different fracture line pattern than what was shown in the image.

 

Option C. C-shaped fracture: Has a curved fracture line resembling the letter C, which is different from the pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual BW

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about the initial setting? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tidal volume – 12 ml/kg of actual BW 

 

  • Incorrect Setting: The generally recommended starting tidal volume for many patients, especially those at risk for or with established acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is closer to 6 ml/kg of ideal body weight. Using 12 ml/kg of actual body weight can potentially lead to lung injury, especially in patients with pre-existing lung pathology or those who are at risk, such as trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate - 12 Breaths/min: This is a typical starting point for the respiratory rate (RR) in many mechanically ventilated adults. The RR can be adjusted based on the patient's metabolic needs, acid-base balance, and CO2 levels.

 

Option B. PEEP - 5 cm H2O: Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) helps keep alveoli open at the end of expiration, improving oxygenation and potentially preventing alveolar collapse. A starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O is a common initial setting in many ventilated patients, and it can be titrated based on oxygenation needs and potential hemodynamic effects.

 

Option C. FiO2 - 100%: Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) refers to the concentration of oxygen in the gas mixture. Starting with a high FiO2, like 100%, ensures that the patient is receiving the maximum amount of oxygen. However, it's important to titrate this down as quickly as clinically feasible to avoid potential oxygen toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient started on mechanical ventilation, ideal ventilatory settings include a tidal volume of 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight, a respiratory rate of 12-18 breaths/min, an initial FiO2 of 100% titrated down to maintain SpO2 > 95%, and a starting PEEP of 5 cm H2O. Using a tidal volume of 12 ml/kg of actual body weight is incorrect and can lead to lung injury.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2660

choices.text: Swan Neck deformity
Boutonniere deformity
Jersey Finger
Mallet Finger

questions.text: Identify the deformity:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Swan Neck deformity

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
    • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
      • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles
      • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
      • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Others:
      • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
      • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
      • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
      • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:
    • Hand:
      • ‘Z-deformity’, i.e. radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of the digits, often with palmar subluxation of proximal phalanges.
      • Boutonniere deformity i.e. flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.
      • Swan neck deformity i.e. hyperextension of PIP joints with compensatory flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints.

 

 

  • Elbow:
  • Flexion deformity
  • Knee:
  • Early: Flexion deformity
  • Late: Triple subluxation
  • Ankle:
  • Equinus deformity
  • Foot:
  • Hallux valgus, Hammer toe, etc.
  • Radiological Features:
  • Reduced joint space
  • Erosion of articular margins
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Juxta-articular rarefaction
  • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
  • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Boutonniere deformity. It is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.

 

 

Option C. Jersey finger. It is avulsion of FDP from distal phalanx. There is hyperextension of a flexed finger as in finger trapped in a jersey. Ring finger most commonly affected. Treatment is surgical.

 

 

Option D. Mallet finger. It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx. It may be due to direct trauma, but more often occurs when the finger tip is forcibly bent during active extension (i.e. sudden occurrence of passive flexion of distal interphalangeal joint). The terminal phalanx is flexed, but passive movement is normal. The proximal interphalangeal joint may become hyper- extended due to unbalanced extensor mechanism (Swan neck). Three types are a tendinous avulsion (X-ray is normal), a small flake of bone or a large dorsal bone fragment, (some times with subluxation of Joints).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of Swan Neck Deformity, which is seen in the cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

questions.text: Identify the PTA. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed

 

The audiogram shows characteristics of mixed hearing loss where both conductive and sensorineural components are present:

 

  • There is an air-bone gap (separation between air and bone conduction curves) indicating a conductive component
  • The bone conduction curve is below normal (>25 dB) indicating sensorineural component
  • The air conduction shows even greater hearing loss (50-70 dB)
  • Both curves are below normal range but maintain a gap between them

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHL (Conductive Hearing Loss): In pure conductive hearing loss, bone conduction would be normal (within 25 dB) with only air conduction being affected, creating an air-bone gap. Here bone conduction is also affected.

 

Option B. SNHL (Sensorineural Hearing Loss): In pure SNHL, both air and bone conduction curves would be affected but would be close together without significant gap. Here there is a clear air-bone gap.

 

Option D. None: The audiogram clearly shows pathological findings and cannot be considered normal where both curves would be within 25 dB with no gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed hearing loss, the audiogram shows both bone conduction below normal (SNHL component) and an air-bone gap (conductive component), indicating pathology in both inner ear and middle/outer ear.

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap(AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

 

  1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
  2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
  3. Watch for Headache and nasal discharge
  4. Monitor glucose levels
  5. Watch for Sinusitis-like symptoms
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

Discharging a COVID-19 patient involves providing instructions for monitoring ongoing or potential symptoms and managing side effects of treatments such as steroids and remdesivir.

 

3. Watch for headache and nasal discharge: These symptoms can be part of the post-COVID syndrome or could indicate secondary infections like sinusitis, especially after treatment that might suppress the immune system.

 

4. Monitor glucose levels: Steroids, often used in the treatment of severe COVID-19, can elevate blood glucose levels. It’s crucial for patients, especially those with pre-existing diabetes or those who experienced high glucose levels during treatment, to monitor their levels after discharge.

 

5. Watch for sinusitis-like symptoms: As with headache and nasal discharge, symptoms like those of sinusitis might suggest secondary infections, which are important to monitor given the use of immunomodulating treatments like steroids.

 

Other Options:
 

1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge: Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge is not required as per updated guidelines. Repeat RT-PCR at 7 days of discharge was initially suggested, but later on removed from the guideline. 
 

2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia: Watch for the persistence of Anosmia is a common symptom (Anosmia can persist for weeks together) but, not matching with the options (actual answer should be 2,3,4, and 5).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients recovering from COVID-19 should monitor for symptoms of headache and nasal discharge, glucose levels due to steroid use, and sinusitis-like symptoms which could indicate secondary infections like mucormycosis.

choices.text: Deletion of gene

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is typically associated with alterations in the SRY gene, which is crucial for initiating male sex determination. The SRY gene, located on the Y chromosome, directs the development of the gonads into testes. When this gene is deleted, it results in a failure to initiate testis formation, leading to a phenotypically female individual with a 46XY karyotype. In 10-15% of cases of 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, the SRY gene deletion is the underlying cause. This leads to a failure in developing male characteristics and results in complete gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point mutation: Point mutations in the SRY gene can also lead to gonadal dysgenesis, but this accounts for only a small percentage of cases. The mutations typically involve changes in the DNA sequence that alter the function of the SRY protein but do not necessarily delete the gene.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation refers to the movement of the SRY gene to another chromosome, which can sometimes lead to sex reversal if the SRY gene is present on an X chromosome in a 46XX individual. However, this is not the primary mechanism for complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversions involve a segment of the chromosome being reversed end to end. This type of chromosomal rearrangement is less commonly associated with gonadal dysgenesis and is not a typical cause of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

questions.text: What is the procedure being done in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stapedotomy

 

The image shows a stapedotomy procedure where:

 

  • The stapes suprastructure has been removed
  • A piston prosthesis is being inserted between the long process of incus and stapes footplate
  • A small fenestration is made in the footplate to connect middle ear with inner ear
  • This is the treatment of choice for otosclerosis where the stapes footplate is fixed in the oval window
  • The prosthesis restores the ossicular chain continuity and sound transmission

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This involves repairing the tympanic membrane perforation using temporalis fascia or tragal perichondrium graft. The image shows intervention at the level of stapes, not tympanic membrane.

 

Option C. Ossiculoplasty: While this involves reconstruction of ossicular chain, it specifically refers to reconstruction of malleus and incus using either autologous or prosthetic materials (TORP/PORP). The image shows specific intervention at stapes level.

 

Option D. Mastoidectomy: This involves drilling the mastoid bone behind the ear to remove diseased tissue/bone. The image shows middle ear surgery focused on stapes, not mastoid surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Stapedotomy is the surgical procedure of choice for otosclerosis, involving removal of fixed stapes suprastructure and placement of a piston prosthesis to restore sound transmission.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

DIFFUSE IDIOPATHIC SKELETAL HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spon­dyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a noninflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is characterized by florid hyperostosis of the spine.
  • Marginal bony proliferation leads to the formation of anterior osseous ridges that fuse and give the appearance of flowing wax on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae on radiography.
  • Ossification of paraspinous ligaments, such as the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, may be seen.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankylosis occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • The thoracic spine is most commonly involved, although the cervical and lumbar regions may also be affected.
  • Lesions are most prominent anteriorly and along the right lateral aspect of the spine.
  • Intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, unless there is co-existing lumbar spondylosis, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal. This helps differentiate diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis from spondylosis and the spondyloarthritis.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is usually seen in the middle-aged and the elderly.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death. Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • DISH may be discovered as a radiological abnormality, as mentioned above, without any symptoms.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Calcification and ossification may be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease. It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients. Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis. It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years. Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity. Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation. Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation. Spine radiograph shows loss of lumbar lordosis, haziness of SI joint margins (earliest change), calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign), Trolley/Tram-track sign i.e., three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification, Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Option C. Klippel feil syndrome. It is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of limited neck motion, low hair line and short ‘web' neck (prominent trapezius muscle). Clinical features includes abnormal head position, true torticollis, restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture, congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

choices.text: Cell mediated and antibody mediated response

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cell mediated response

 

A Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T cells that provoke an inflammatory reaction against exogenous or endogenous antigens. In certain situations, other cells, such as monocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils, can be involved. After antigen exposure, an initial local immune and inflammatory response occurs that attracts leukocytes. The antigen engulfed by the macrophages and monocytes is presented to T cells, which then becomes sensitized and activated. These cells then release cytokines and chemokines, which can cause tissue damage and may result in illnesses. It is considered a delayed hypersensitivity reaction because it usually occurs more than 12 hours after exposure to the allergen, with a maximal reaction time between 48 and 72 hours.

 

Examples of illnesses resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell mediated and antibody mediated response: This is not correct for Type IV hypersensitivity, which is exclusively cell-mediated and does not involve antibodies.

 

Option C. Antibody mediated response: This describes Type I, II, and III hypersensitivities, which involve IgE, IgG, or IgM antibodies, respectively. Type IV is exclusively cell-mediated.

 

Option D. Innate response: While the innate immune response involves cells like macrophages and neutrophils, Type IV hypersensitivity specifically involves the adaptive immune system, particularly T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated response primarily involving T cells and other immune cells, leading to delayed-type reactions such as contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

The four types of hypersensitivity are:

 

  1. Type I: reaction mediated by IgE antibodies
  2. Type II: cytotoxic reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies
  3. Type III: reaction mediated by immune complexes
  4. Type IV: delayed reaction mediated by cellular response

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

 

Explanation: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.


Entry Inhibitors

 

 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Maraviroc: This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.

 

Option D. Tenofovir: This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

choices.text: Dystrophic with increased serum calcium
Metastatic with increased serum calcium
Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

 

Atheromatous plaques show dystrophic calcification in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

 

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

 

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type -

 

Calcification in dead tissue –

 

  1. Caseous necrosis in tuberculosis is the most common site for dystrophic calcification.
  2. Liquefaction necrosis in chronic abscesses may get calcified.
  3. Fat necrosis following acute pancreatitis or traumatic fat necrosis in the breast results in deposition of calcium soaps.
  4. Gamma-Gandy bodies in chronic venous congestion (CVC. of the spleen is characterized by calcific deposits admixed with hemosiderin on fibrous tissue.
  5. Infarcts may sometimes undergo dystrophic calcification.
  6. Thrombi, especially in the veins, may produce phleboliths.
  7. Hematomas in the vicinity of bones may undergo dystrophic calcification.
  8. Dead parasites like in hydatid cyst, Schistosoma eggs, and cysticercosis are some of the examples showing dystrophic calcification.
  9. Calcification in breast cancer detected by mammography.
  10. Congenital toxoplasmosis involving the central nervous system visualized by calcification in the infant brain.

 

Calcification in degenerated tissues

 

  1. Dense old scars may undergo hyaline degeneration and subsequent calcification.
  2. Atheromatous in the aorta and coronaries frequently undergo calcification.
  3. Mönckeberg’s sclerosis shows calcification in the tunica media of muscular arteries in elderly people
  4. Stroma of tumors such as uterine fibroids, breast cancer, thyroid adenoma, goitre etc. show calcification.
  5. Some tumors show characteristic spherules of calcification called psammoma bodies or calcospherites such as in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
  6. Cysts which have been present for a long time may show calcification of their walls e.g. epidermal and pilar cysts.
  7. Calcinosis cutis is a condition of unknown cause in which there are irregular nodular deposits of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  8. Senile degenerative changes may be accompanied by dystrophic calcification such as in costal cartilages, tracheal or bronchial cartilages, and pineal gland in the brain etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystrophic with increased serum calcium: Dystrophic calcification typically occurs in the setting of normal serum calcium levels. While hypercalcemia can exacerbate dystrophic calcification, it is not a defining feature.

 

Option B. Metastatic with increased serum calcium: Metastatic calcification occurs when calcium salts are deposited in normal tissues as a result of hypercalcemia. This form of calcification is not associated with tissue injury or necrosis and typically affects tissues like the lungs, stomach, kidneys, and blood vessels under conditions of high serum calcium. It does not apply to the situation described, where calcification is occurring in damaged tissue with normal calcium levels.

 

Option D. Metastatic with normal serum calcium: This option is incorrect because metastatic calcification is always associated with hypercalcemia, not normal serum calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 83

choices.text: Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension
Obstructive Sleep Apnea

questions.text: Inhaled NO is used in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension

 

Inhaled nitric oxide (NO) is a potent pulmonary vasodilator used primarily in the management of various conditions associated with elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Its primary uses include:

 

  • Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension (A): Inhaled NO is used to reduce pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular afterload in patients with primary pulmonary hypertension. It helps improve oxygenation and reduce symptoms associated with this condition.
  • Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Inhaled NO can be used to lower pulmonary pressures and relieve right ventricular strain.
  • Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH): Inhaled NO is used for vasoreactivity testing and to manage secondary forms of PAH.
  • Right Ventricular Failure in STEMI: Particularly in inferior STEMI with right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI), inhaled NO can reduce right ventricular afterload.
  • Refractory Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Used as a bridging therapy to improve oxygenation until a more definitive treatment, such as lung transplantation, is available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: This condition is typically managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy and lifestyle modifications.

 

Option C. Unstable Angina: Managed with anti-anginal medications, antiplatelet therapy, and revascularization procedures as needed.

 

Option D. Erectile Dysfunction: Treated with phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil), hormone therapy, or mechanical devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled nitric oxide is primarily used to manage conditions with elevated pulmonary artery pressures, such as primary pulmonary artery hypertension. It is not used for obstructive sleep apnea, unstable angina, or erectile dysfunction.
